webTitle: Tesco rapped for implying horsemeat scandal affected whole food industry

fields.bodyText: Tesco has been criticised by the advertising watchdog for claiming that the horsemeat scandal affected the entire food industry. The Advertising Standards Agency (ASA) ruled that an ad run by Tesco in February, at the height of the food crisis, "implied that all retailers and suppliers were likely to have sold products contaminated with horsemeat" when "relatively few instances of contamination had been identified at the time". The ad now banned by the ASA, entitled "What burgers have taught us", said: "The problem we've had with some of our meat lately is about more than burgers and bolognese. It's about some of the ways we get meat to your dinner table. It's about the whole food industry." Two people, including an independent butcher, complained that the ad was misleading because it implied there were issues with meat standards across the whole food industry, unfairly denigrating suppliers who had not been involved in the supply of mislabelled products. The news comes at a sensitive time for the UK's biggest supermarket as it attempts to rebuild its reputation and market share in the wake of the scandal and problems with customer service. It recently launched a high profile ad campaign called "Love Every Mouthful" in a bid to highlight the quality of its food after promising to source more meat from the UK and Ireland and step up testing to avoid future contamination. Tesco's share price plummeted in January after tests carried out by Ireland's food watchdog identified traces of horsemeat in burgers sold in its stores, as well as Iceland, Aldi and Lidl. Tesco launched an internal investigation and placed a series of national newspaper ads apologising for the incident and explaining how it planned to change. In response to the ruling Tesco said it accepted that not all those involved in the food industry had been implicated in the sale of products containing horsemeat. Rival supermarkets including Sainsbury's, Marks & Spencer and Waitrose were never found to have sourced food contaminated with horsemeat. However Tesco said it had not operated in a vaccuum and the meat contamination problem it and others had encountered was due to systemic failings in the food supply chain. It submitted opinion and evidence from an expert to back that view, which the supermarket said was supported by the actions of the European commission and planned legislation on the supply chain which would apply to the whole European food industry. A spokesman said: "We are disappointed with this decision, but accept that the ASA has taken a very literal view of the wording in the advert. We think our customers understood that our aim with the advert was to set out the action we had taken in relation to the horsemeat crisis and to acknowledge the fact the issue had serious consequences not just for Tesco, but for the whole of the food industry." The ASA said the ad made the "definitive statement" that the crisis was "about the whole food industry" and concluded that consumers would understand that it referred to all food suppliers rather than Tesco alone. However it said the ad did not denigrate other companies because it did not name any particular supplier.

webTitle: GlaxoSmithKline's tussle with China is getting messier and riskier

fields.standfirst: The significance is that – if proved – it would be harder for GSK to argue that it is the victim of a few rogue elements
fields.body:
Seven weeks after GlaxoSmithKline was accused of wrongdoing in China, the allegations keep coming. The latest twist is the claim by Chinese police to have discovered an organised bribery ring within GSK's local office.

The significance of that tale is that – if proved – it would be harder for the company to argue that it is the victim of a few rogue elements within its workforce. The alleged corrupt practices would look more like a case of systemic malpractice, which could conceivably make GSK vulnerable to charges under UK or US anti-bribery laws.

At the moment, let's be clear, we are still talking about allegations. And some of the latest Chinese claims, to judge by the details in a state media report, look far from being a slam-dunk. For example, it is hard to understand why merely setting a target of 25% for sales growth could in itself constitute an inducement to salespeople to engage in illegal practices.

But what is clear is that the Chinese authorities are not letting go of this affair. Back in July it was possible to believe – just – that the journey from crisis to resolution would be swift. GSK would pay a modest fine, pledge to improve its monitoring of staff and some new form of working relationship would quickly emerge in which the Chinese state enjoyed lower prices for medicines.

Some or all of those elements may yet emerge, but settlement still seems miles away. By this stage GSK would surely have hoped to have got beyond the "deeply concerned" stage. Instead, the tale is getting messier – and riskier.

fields.standfirst: Burberry has launched Brit Rhythm a perfume for men its first fragrance since taking its beauty business in-house in April
fields.body:
Burberry has launched its first fragrance since taking the running of its beauty business in-house in April.

The luxury British brand, famous for its raincoats, gave Brit Rhythm, a perfume for men, a typically multimedia birth with a campaign embracing Twitter, live gigs and scented temporary tattoos available online.

The perfume will also be promoted via a dedicated website incorporating music, editorial and videos produced in partnership with Noisey, part of the hipster magazine group Vice Media.

Burberry paid €181m (£154m) to end its licence relationship with its previous partner, Interparfums, at the end of March as it said it wanted to capitalise on the "significant opportunities" available in the fragrance and beauty market by developing products more rapidly and linking them to the rest of its activities. The company earned £27m from fragrance and beauty royalties from Interparfums last year.

Angela Ahrendts, chief executive, said that future growth would come from "one consistent brand expression leveraged across all categories".

Historically, Burberry led product design, packaging and marketing activities for its perfumes and beauty but will now oversee product development, sourcing and logistics, working with external distributors. Burberry already sells the Brit, London and Weekend fragrances for men and women and has several more for women only including Body and Sheer.

webTitle: Wonga joins ranks of top UK lenders

fields.bodyText: One million hard-pressed borrowers prepared to pay interest at up to 5,853% have propelled Wonga.com into the league of Britain's biggest lenders after the controversial payday loan company lent as much money last year as Britain's biggest building society advanced in personal loans. The Archbishop of Canterbury's promise to "compete Wonga out of existence" has failed to dent the group's frenetic expansion, it emerged on Tuesday, as Wonga said its profits had leapt by more than a third to £62.5m, with the number of loans granted growing even faster. During 2012 it handed out nearly four million loans, worth a total of £1.2bn, to one million customers in Britain, matching the amount Nationwide granted in personal loans. "Digital savvy" consumers are flocking to Wonga, said founder and chief executive Errol Damelin, whose salary increased by £119,000 to £754,000 over the year, with his personal shareholding estimated to be worth more than £30m. On ITV he compared taking a loan from Wonga to buying a song on iTunes. "This is not about people on breadlines being desperate … this is about us serving customers who want to take a loan and know they can pay it back in three days – that is in the same way that they want to buy one song on iTunes." But when Wonga chairman Robin Klein was asked if he would be happy about his own child taking a loan from Wonga, he said: "I would tell them to come to me instead." Stella Creasy, the Labour MP who has campaigned against payday lenders, said the news of Wonga's profits "should be of great concern to all of us in Britain". "What that says about families who are struggling financially, what it says about the kind of regulation we currently have in the UK and the things we need to do to make sure people in Britain can borrow affordably – Wonga might be celebrating today [but] I am very, very concerned about what this might mean for people in my community and across the country who are paying the price for their profits." Wonga's breakneck pace of expansion has overshadowed the credit unions that the archbishop, Justin Welby, said he hoped to promote but which have so far failed to emerge as an alternative to the payday lenders. Wonga alone is now three times the size of all the 390 credit unions in Britain, which last year lent just £407m in total. But Damelin said the credit union idea promoted by the archbishop would require state handouts and said he opposed Labour proposals for a levy on payday lenders to fund their development. The archbishop's attack on Wonga caused him acute embarrassment when it emerged shortly afterwards that the Church of England's pension fund was indirectly an investor in Wonga. Wonga plans now to try to repeat its success abroad. The company saidon Tuesday it had "ambitions far beyond short-term consumer loans in the UK" with its business in South Africa growing rapidly over the past year. It also operates in Russia, Canada and Poland. Meanwhile in Britain the company is aiming to fill the gap left by the high street banks in the small business market, with the launch of WongaForBusiness.com. Damelin said that nearly a quarter of loans taken out by Wonga customers are repaid early, and that it is a responsible lender, rejecting about three quarters of first-loan applications. But the accounts reveal that it wrote off £96m and made a £126m provision for customers defaulting in 2012, double the levels of 2011. Trade union Unite said the financial results demonstrated the need for legislation to curb payday lenders. "Payday lenders are making their profits on those struggling to make ends meet on a daily basis with outrageous rates of interest that mount up with an alarming speed, causing fear and insecurity," the general secretary, Len McCluskey, said. "Ted Heath once spoke of the unacceptable face of capitalism – what we are seeing in 2013 is vulture capitalism, picking wallets and purses clean."

fields.body:
5.54pm BST

And finally....

Trading is over in Helsinki, after a day dominated by the news that Nokia was selling its mobile handset operations to Microsoft.

Shares in Nokia finished the day up almost 34% at €3.97, up one euro. The cost of insuring its debt against default almost halved, data provider Markit reported.

While over on Wall Street, US investors continue to view the deal with suspicion. Shares in Microsoft are down 6.2%, shedding two cents to $31.34. I outlined some reasons for the fall here.

European stock markets finished the day mostly in the red. There was a late sell-off after John Boehner, the US Republican Speaker in Congress, backed president Obama's call for military action against the Syrian regime.

Here's the closing prices:

• FTSE 100: down 37 points at 6468, - 0.6%

• German DAX: down 63 points at 8180, -0,77%

• French CAC: down 31 points at 3974, -0.8%

• Italian FTSE MIB: down 47 points at 16941, -0.28%

• Spanish IBEX: up 15 points at 8445, + 0.2%

Michael Hewson of CMC Markets reminds us that the markets also had a morning wobble over the Middle East (see 10.15am for details):

European markets have had a slightly less exuberant air about them today after the strong gains of yesterday as nervousness about the situation in the Middle East spilled over on reports of two ballistic missiles being fired in the Mediterranean, caused markets to slump sharply in the morning session.

Markets did regain their equilibrium somewhat after it was confirmed that it was a missile test by Israel but it was a timely reminder of the fluidity and uncertainty of the situation in the region, and kept investors on the back foot somewhat throughout the remainder of the day, despite some positive US economic data (see 4.54pm).

And that's a good moment to stop today's live blog. Thank you, as ever, for reading and commenting. Back tomorrow! GW

Spanish unemployment falls, by one person a day

Missed this earlier... the Spanish unemployment total fell in August, by just 31 people.

The Labour Ministry reported that the registered jobless total fell last month, for the first August since 2000. But with almost six million out of work, much more needs to be done.

Economy minister Luis de Guindos told Cadena Ser radio that Spain had hit the 'bottom' now:

There's a stabilization in the jobs market, and I'd say this is a reason for hope. There's a great deal more to do ... but I'd say we've hit bottom. In the second part of this year we'll see slight (economic) growth.

More encouraging news for the global economy this afternoon: America's manufacturing sector has posted its strongest growth since July 2011.

Wall Street correspondent Dominic Rushe writes that the data (held over from Monday because of Labor Day) beat forecasts:

US manufacturing expanded in August at the fastest pace since June 2011, according to a closely watched poll of the sector.

Economic activity in the manufacturing sector expanded for the third consecutive month, according to the Institute of Supply Management (ISM). The ISM poll of purchasing managers rose to 55.7% from 55.4% in July – readings above 50% indicate growth in the manufacturing sector.

The poll was better than forecast and comes before the latest monthly job figures are released by the Labor Department on Friday.

Yesterday we saw strong manufacturing data from the UK and most eurozone countries, although India's factory sector suffered falling activity.

Microsoft-Nokia: What the readers say

Thanks, as ever, for the comments below the line. Here's a selection on the Microsoft-Nokia deal:

4.33pm BST

Meanwhile, in the Eurozone....

Regular readers have been berating me 'below the line' for the lack of coverage of the eurozone debt crisis today.

In truth, there's not that much going on (Merkel's jousting in the Bundesbank was the early highlight). But Open Europe, the think tank, has published a survey of German voters' views on the euro, which is rather interesting.

Key findings include:

• 55% believe the eurozone would be better if it were restricted to a group of 'similar countries:

Reverting to the Deutsche-mark is only backed by one-third of voters (32%) versus 60% opposing it, with a similar breakdown on the option of breaking up the euro completely (30% tend to agree, 59% tend to disagree).

46% said the euro shouldn’t be saved “at any cost”, while 42% said it should. 42% said they agree the euro is now threatening the European project – only marginally lower than those who say it does not (45%).

• Voters don't want to see further financial assistance to the euro area:

Almost two-thirds (65%) said the next Chancellor would only have the mandate to sign up to more money going to other eurozone countries if a referendum was held. 

More here.

Slate sums up the lacklustre response to Microsoft's big deal, saying the tech giant has "cemented its also-ran status" in the mobile world.

Microsoft...will go from being a minor afterthought in the mobile devices and services world to a much larger afterthought. Google, Apple, and Samsung may not exactly be quaking in their boots this morning, but BlackBerry is pretty much screwed.

3.57pm BST

Favourite Nokia phone?

Personally, my favourite Nokia handset was the 7110 with the spring-loaded cover (as seen in the "The Matrix")

Sadly our love affair was ended by a London bag-snatcher back in 2001 (yes, I'm still cross about it).

3.43pm BST

3.37pm BST

The Economist also homes in on Stephen Elop's chequered time at Nokia:

3.20pm BST

Why are Microsoft's shares down?

It's early days, but a 4% fall in Microsoft's shares today shows that investors and analysts aren't convinced that buying Nokia's mobile devices and services arm is the path to glory? So why not?

1) It's hardly a transformational deal. Nokia has been tied to Microsoft's banner for the last two years, and the drop in market share has been steady (as we showed at 1.12pm). The Lumia range gets good reviews, but Android and Apple devices still dominate.

Buying Nokia suggests Microsoft doesn't have a better plan to crack the mobile space (and may mean there isn't one)

2) Could it backfire? Nokia isn't the only firm to make Windows Phone devices, but other vendors could be concerned that Microsoft won't give them priority once it also owns a handset business.

Adrian Drozd of Frost & Sullivan explains:

In order to grow market share, Microsoft will need to keep Samsung and HTC on board, and will need to alleviate any concerns that emerge as a result of the acquisition. Microsoft can use Nokia to really drive innovation on the platform, as Google is doing with Motorola. However, in order to succeed it will need to ensure it maintains good relationships with its partners.

3) Is Elop the Guy to turn Microsoft around? The Nokia deal paves the way for Elop to replace Steve Ballmer as CEO, but has he really earned it?

During his thre years at Nokia, Elop has seen revenues slide and profitability tumble. Not the best track record to take back to Seattle. Also not all his fault -- Nokia was already in deep trouble in 2010.

Technology guru Om Malik was scathing about Elop's performance in Finland, writing:

Stephen Elop’s tenure as the chief executive of Nokia would at best earn him a B-minus grade, and that much because he inherited a company that was spiraling down before he showed up. The “bet the farm on Windows Phone move” however was all him. Since taking over the reins at Nokia in 2010, Elop has seen smartphone sales shrink faster than a $5-dollar linen shirt.

If anything, Elop’s tenure at the top of Nokia will be remembered for the years when Nokia became irrelevant in the the mobile handset business. In a post, “The End of the (Nokia) Raj”, I hinted at a future of irrelevance for Nokia. The fall from grace came much sooner than even I thought. Elop is now being widely tipped to take over Microsoft as its next chief executive, replacing outgoing Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer. Given his track record, if I were a Microsoft shareholder, I would have to pause and gulp hard before putting the future of the company in his hands.

More here: Why I think the $7.2 billion Microsoft-Nokia deal is a terrible idea

3.00pm BST

Shares in Nokia, though, are still up around 40%.

Nokia will still continue as an independent company once Microsoft subsumes its handset division. It is keeping its interests in telecoms equipment, and €5.4bn better off. The better half of the deal?....

Barry Collins, editor of the UK's PC Pro magazine, fears job losses ahead at Nokia's handset arm:

2.22pm BST

Summary: Microsoft-Nokia deal so far

Parts of America are digesting the news of the Microsoft-Nokia deal (it was announced at 11pm New York time), so here's a round-up of the main events so far today.

• Nokia's reign as an independent mobile phone maker is over, after Microsoft agreed a €5.4bn/$7.2bn deal to take control of its mobile handsets and services division. Full coverage from the start of this blog.

• Steve Ballmer's last big deal (probably) before he steps down as Microsoft's chief executive sent Nokia's shares soaring by 40% this morning. In an email to staff, Ballmer said the acquisition would build on the "incredible work" achieved since the two firms teamed up in 2011.

• Ballmer has appeared in Helsinki to discuss the deal, calling it a "win-win" and "a bold step into the future". (details and photos here).

• Microsoft hopes the deal can help it to finally break the smartphone market that is dominated by Apple and Samsung. But analysts warn that it faces an uphill battle (see 11.34am).

As CCS Insight put it:

The challenge of integrating the two businesses should not be underestimated, especially at a time when Microsoft is in the middle of its biggest ever reorganisation.

• Nokia's CEO, Stephen Elop, will rejoin Microsoft - a company he left three years ago to run Nokia. Bookmakers have already slashed the odds on him replacing Ballmer (latest odds here)

• For Nokia, the move ends its long association with the mobile handset market, which it helped to create. Finnish government minister said he hoped the deal could benefit both sides, but warned that Nokia staff need protecting (see 9.09am)

Nokia deal explained in graphs

Stephen Elop is the odds-on favourite to become Microsoft's next CEO (see 8.51am), but do you think he's got what it takes to replace Steve Ballmer and take the company forward? (at 10.16am Moscow time, or 7.16am BST) Just shows how jittery the markets can be.... webTitle: FTSE falls back on Syria worries but AB Foods lifted by upgrade

fields.standfirst: Leading shares end lower as action in Syria draws closer and profit takers move in at Vodafone
fields.body:
As profit takers moved in after Monday's surge, amid reports of missile launches in the Mediterranean and growing support for US action in Syria, there were some bright spots.

Associated British Foods added 23p to £19.01 after analysts at Exane BNP Paribas raised their recommendation on the groceries, sugar and Primark business from underperform to outperform and their target price by 28% to £24. The bank warned that changes in the sugar market were likely to depress profits in the sector, but ABF's other businesses - especially Primark - would take up the slack. They said:

The European sugar market operates under a highly regulated regime that stifles competition. This world will end in September 2017. When it does, we see severe profit compression for all European sugar industry participants.
[So] why move to outperform in an apocalypse? Put simply, the sugar bear case is dead. While the new regime will materially impact [ABF's] sugar profits (we look for a decline of around 50% in Europe), this represents only a 9% drag on the group in 2018 (when Primark will represent 63% of earnings). Over the next three years (2013 to 2016) we look for a 13% earnings per share compound annual growth, a 1 point PE ratchet (the Primark mix effect) and for ABF to turn net cash. We will not stand in the way of a juggernaut.

Overall the FTSE 100 fell 37.78 points to 6468.41 despite an opening rise on Wall Street, which was effectively playing catch-up after being closed for Monday's Labor Day holiday.

The UK market suffered a jolt downwards in mid-morning after Russian reports of missiles being fired in the Mediterranean, renewing fears of an attack on Syria. A certain amount of calm returned when the US and Israel said it was just a test, but it was a reminder that the situation remains volatile. Later came comments from US House speaker John Boehner backing a Syria war resolution, adding to the likelihood of Congress voting for US action. Michael Hewson, senior market analyst at CMC Markets UK, said:

European markets have had a slightly less exuberant air about them today after the strong gains of yesterday as nervousness about the situation in the Middle East spilled over on reports of two ballistic missiles being fired in the Mediterranean, caused markets to slump sharply in the morning session.
Markets did regain their equilibrium somewhat after it was confirmed that it was a missile test by Israel but it was a timely reminder of the fluidity and uncertainty of the situation in the region, and kept investors on the back foot somewhat throughout the remainder of the day, despite some positive US economic data.

Vodafone was the biggest faller, down 10.7p at 202.5p on profit taking following confirmation it had agreed to sell its stake in Verizon Wireless for $130bn.

A second major technology deal in two days - Microsoft's purchase of Nokia's handset business - also caused some excitement, with Nokia shares sharply higher but Microsoft heading in the opposite direction.

Centrica climbed 4.2p to 393.1p as Deutsche Bank moved from hold to neutral on the British Gas owner, and raised its price target from 340p to 430p.

But property shares came under pressure following a note on the sector from analysts at JP Morgan Cazenove.

Its top picks included Land Securities, but even there it cut its target price from £11.10 to £10.40. The company - which is also behind the Walkie Talkie building in London which appears to be focusing the sun's rays in a way which melts cars - dropped 27.5p to 881p. Cazenove reduced its target price on British Land, down 14.5p to 552.5p, from 720p to 670p, and moved Capital & Counties, 10.3p lower at 314.7p, from overweight to neutral.

Among the mid-caps Spirent Communications rose 6p to 134.8p after the telecoms testing company said chief executive Bill Burns was stepping down immediately, to be replaced by finance director Eric Hutchinson. The company gave no reason for the change, and said it would start the search for a new chief executive in due course.

Meanwhile TalkTalk Telecom put on 5.5p to 253.5p following a positive note from JP Morgan. The bank said TalkTalk's shares had been unfairly hit by news that BT would be offering its sports channel free to its broadband customers. It said:

Over the last year, TalkTalk has beaten expectations on TV adds and churn reduction, while pricing repair continues. The cost story is compelling with much still to do given its acquisitive history. Despite this, it has performed in-line with the FTSE 250 over 12 months, as overdone concerns on BT Sport weigh. We upgrade to overweight (from neutral) and increase our price target to 300p (from 225p).

Elsewhere Genus, the animal genetics business, fell 131p to £13.48 after underlying full year profits dropped from £54.4m to £38.1m reflecting a fall in biological assets. Adjusted profits rose by 1% to £49.1m. Panmure Gordon moved from sell to hold, saying:

Genus has reported 2013 results slightly below our forecasts with adjusted earnings per share rising 3% to 55p (Panmure 56p). However anticipated good harvests in the Northern Hemisphere are likely to lower input costs and improve profitability in major end markets. As such Genus expects to deliver strong progress through 2014. We forecast a return more typical mid-teens earnings growth in 2014.

webTitle: US manufacturing expands at fastest rate since July 2011

fields.standfirst: Institute of Supply Management poll better than forecast, although concerns remain over Fed's quantitative easing plans
fields.body:
US manufacturing expanded in August at the fastest pace since June 2011, according to a closely watched poll of the sector.

Economic activity in the manufacturing sector expanded for the third consecutive month, according to the Institute of Supply Management (ISM). The ISM poll of purchasing managers rose to 55.7% from 55.4% in July – readings above 50% indicate growth in the manufacturing sector.

The poll was better than forecast and comes before the latest monthly job figures are released by the Labor Department on Friday. Of the 18 manufacturing industries measured by the ISM, 15 reported growth – including textile mills, food and beverage, computer and electronic products and transportation equipment. Only one industry, miscellaneous manufacturing, reported contraction in August.

However, respondents to the survey remained cautious, one calling improvements "slight" in a remark quoted by ISM. "Tight government spending still affecting business," reported one transportation equipment executive. "Military slowdown affecting business," said a computer and electronics executive.

The ISM report comes amid concerns about the Federal Reserve's plans to pull back on quantitative easing, its $85bn-a-month bond-buying programme aimed at encouraging investment.

"Following any economic report these days, all roads lead to the effect, or lack thereof, on Fed asset purchases. So in that regard, today's report does nothing to dissuade the Fed from pulling back on purchases. As for the broader economic impact, today's report is entirely consistent with the moderate expansion we've been experiencing," Dan Greenhaus, chief global strategist at broker BTIG, wrote in a note to investors.

The next big test of the strength of the US economy comes on Friday, with the release of the latest non-farm payroll report. US employers slowed the pace of hiring in July, adding 162,000 new jobs – down from 188,000 in June. But the unemployment rate continued to fall, reaching 7.4%, its lowest level in more than four years.

webTitle: GSK ran hospital bribery programme, say Chinese police

fields.standfirst: State media report claims wrongdoing was part of GlaxoSmithKline's corporate strategy and not caused by rogue salespeople
fields.body:
Chinese police claim to have found evidence showing GlaxoSmithKline organised a bribery programme targeted at major hospitals at a company level in China, dismissing suggestions that abuses may have been the result of overenthusiastic or rogue sales staff, according to a state media report.

An increasing number of individuals reputedly involved in corrupt payments are said to have made confessions, according to the Xinhua news agency. "As the investigation is moving on, it is becoming clear that it is organised by GSK China rather than drug salespeople's individual behaviour."

GSK issued a statement denying that wrongdoing had been part of a sanctioned corporate strategy. "The issues identified would be a clear breach of our corporate values and we have zero tolerance for any behaviour of this nature."

GSK accepted in July that some of its executives appear to have "acted outside of our processes and our controls to both defraud the company and the Chinese healthcare system". The drug firm is accused of funnelling up to 3bn yuan (£312m) to travel agencies to facilitate bribes to doctors and officials.

The GSK chief executive, Sir Andrew Witty, told investors the company's headquarters had "no sense" of the "shameful" and "deeply disappointing" allegations.

Tuesday's report from the Xinhua news agency quoted Huang Hong, a general manager for GSK in China and one of the detained executives, saying the company had set goals for annual sales growth as high as 25% – 7% to 8% higher than the average growth rate for the industry.

"Huang admitted that the growth rate of sales could not reach such a high number only by the efforts of the salespeople themselves if there was no dubious corporate behaviour," Xinhua reported.

Chinese police reportedly claim to have evidence that GSK China "went through the motions in internal auditing so as not to discover these violations".

The Xinhua report followed an article in the official People's Daily newspaper that quoted Guo Jianhua, head of recruitment at GSK China, saying the company had turned a blind eye to illegality.

"When the problems were exposed, the company pushed all responsibilities to individual employees," Guo said. It was unclear to which problems Guo was referring or if he was one of the detained executives.

Official media routinely get access to detainees in China. Other detained GSK executives have been interviewed on state television.

Bribes in China's drug industry are reportedly commonplace, fuelled in part by low salaries for doctors. A number of other multinational drugs firms are facing investigations similar to the GSK inquiry as whistle-blowers have come forward.

GSK's continuing controversy in China comes after the drugmaker last year reached a $3bn (£1.9bn) deal with criminal prosecutors in the US, pleading guilty to a raft of offences linked to the illegal promotion of drugs. Many of the allegations related to extravagant travel provided to doctors whose business GSK was courting.

webTitle: The British high street: why it's time for the chains to put something back | Bill Grimsey

fields.standfirst: It will take resources and leadership, but we simply can't turn our backs on high streets, says author of Grimsey review
fields.body:
There is a school of thought that's starting to harden into a weary consensus. It goes like this: the high street is doomed. There's nothing we can do about it. We need to stop wasting time on rundown towns full of high streets with boarded-up shops and focus on places where the tills are still ringing and profits are there to be had.

"Don't try to resuscitate the dead," says the Ocado chairman, Sir Stuart Rose, in the BBC series, Robert Peston Goes Shopping. "Concentrate on the living and make the living better."

From a business perspective, I understand this thinking. There are many towns in Britain where crippling overheads make it very hard to make a living. Weak consumer confidence makes the job even harder. But from a social perspective this kind of thinking is disastrous. It creates desolate high streets and alienated communities. It breeds anger and a sense of hopelessness that ends up costing the taxpayer a great deal in the long run.

I've come to the conclusion that we simply can't turn our backs on high streets. Transforming the most challenging high streets into vibrant places where people feel a sense of belonging and community won't be easy. Mary Portas discovered that. But if we simply shrug and accept failure then we're storing up much bigger problems.

The answer, of course, is not to try and rekindle the glories of yesteryear and focus just on shops. High streets will have to be redesigned around community needs. Education, housing, leisure, training, arts and health will all have a big role to play. But making this transformation won't be easy and it'll require a much bigger impetus than the snail pace of ministers who have spectacularly failed to get to grips with the problem.

It will also require significant resources, serious muscle and leadership. That's why I believe the time has come for the major high street players – who've all benefited hugely from a 25-year consumer boom – to put something back into the high streets they're leaving behind to move their stores to an out of town mega-mall culture that's only going to become more dominant.

As someone who's run major retail organisations and spent 45 years in the industry I know how well the big chains have benefited. Their shareholders have enjoyed extremely good returns and continue to do so. Last year Tesco earned £1.4bn of profits, Next £508m and Sainsbury £614m, for example. If a tiny portion of their turnover – we're calling for 0.25% of sales – was invested through a one-off levy in a local economic development fund this could sponsor a wave of social enterprises and new ventures to help dramatically transform the high street.

We estimate this levy would raise around £550m. It would achieve a lot more than the £18m spent on Portas Pilots and leave a lasting and powerful legacy.

Of course, getting businesses to entertain this idea – and they will naturally be resistant – will require a lot of work. They'll want clear assurances that the fund would be wisely spent. It would have to be administered by trustees that include some of the biggest contributors.

There's no denying though that this is achievable. The biggest businesses can and should take it upon themselves to do what government has failed to do: give our high street, a great British institution admired the world over, a fighting chance of not just surviving but building a new model at the heart of communities that will last.

• Bill Grimsey, the former boss of now defunct DIY chain Focus and Big Food Group, the former owner of the Iceland food retailer, launches the Grimsey review, an assessment of the problems for the high street, on Wednesday

webTitle: FTSE recovers poise after missile reports but property groups hit by downgrades

fields.standfirst: Leading shares slump after Russians say missile launches detected in Mediterranean but soon regain ground
fields.body:
The property sector has come under pressure after a hefty broker note.

JP Morgan Cazenove has cut its recommendation and target prices on a number of UK companies, sending their shares lower. The bank said:

Investment themes have been: prime versus secondary, sell Spain and continental retail versus UK. It is time to rotate to the other side of the trade. We like exposure to infrastructure projects, industrial and Spanish and Dublin offices, but expect the West End magic to fade in 12 months. Over-renting remains an issue and corporate governance matters.

Its top picks include Land Securities, but even there it has cut its target price from £11.10 to £10.40. The company - which is also behind the Walkie Talkie building in London which appears to be focusing the sun's rays in a way which melts cars - is currently down 14.5p at 894p. Cazenove has reduced its target price on British Land, down 7.5p to 559.5p, from 720p to 670p, and moved Capital & Counties, 7.4p lower at 317.6p, from overweight to neutral.

Overall the market has recovered from a sudden plunge mid-morning on Russian reports of missiles being fired in the Mediterranean. The news gave a sharp reminder to investors that the situation in Syria and the Middle East is still volatile, and the FTSE 100 slumped to 6456 before recovering to the current 6499.18, down 7.01 points, on talk it was a US/Israeli test rather than an attack. Matt Basi at CMC Markets said:

European equity markets opened quietly this morning before news of a US missile launch saw stocks offered lowed mid-morning. News that the launch was only a test fire undid some of the intraday damage, but the move did serve to show how the market feels about the prospect of Western intervention in the region, and saw Brent cross back through the $116 mark for the first time this week.

fields.bodyText: Paris-based thinktank the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has lifted its forecast for UK growth in 2013, in the latest vote of confidence for the fledgling recovery. In May, when it last released projections for the world's major economies, the OECD was expecting 0.8% growth in the UK for 2013. On Tuesday, it said recent survey evidence suggested GDP would expand by 1.5%, grouping the UK with the US and Japan as economies where, "activity is expanding at encouraging rates". The upgrade from the OECD comes after a string of positive indicators for the UK, including stronger-than-expected growth of 0.7% in the second quarter, falling unemployment, and survey evidence suggesting the strongest growth in manufacturing output for almost two decades. Alongside revising up its forecast for the UK, the OECD used its interim economic assessment to warn that while a moderate recovery is underway in many major economies, global growth remains sluggish, and there are still risks to the upturn. The OECD's economists single out the impact of the Federal Reserve's plans to phase out its massive programme of quantitative easing as creating particular problems for some economies. "In many emerging economies, loss of domestic activity momentum together with the shift in expectations about the course of monetary policy in the United States and the ensuing rise in global bond yields have led to significant market instability, rising financing costs, capital outflows and currency depreciations," it said. Countries including India, Indonesia, Brazil and Turkey have been battling to control a potentially destabilising decline in their currencies since the Fed chairman, Ben Bernanke, announced his plans to "taper" QE in May. The OECD's experts warn that the slowdown in emerging economies – which have been major drivers of world growth in recent years – would offset the improvement in advanced economies, so that the global recovery would continue to be, "sluggish". In the US, the OECD expects growth to be 1.7% in 2013, slightly down on its May estimate of 1.9%. It also warns that the crisis in the eurozone is far from over, saying: "The euro area remains vulnerable to renewed financial, banking and sovereign debt tensions. Many euro area banks are insufficiently capitalised and weighed down by bad loans."

fields.standfirst: Lending to UK consumers accounted for 3.8m of the 4m loans Wonga advanced in 2012, an increase of 58%
fields.body:
Controversial payday lender Wonga saw its profits soar to more than £1m a week in 2012, as the number of loans it made to British consumers increased by more than 50%.

The lender said profits had been boosted by increased demand from "digital savvy" consumers, but critics accused the company of "vulture capitalism" and said it was making money out of struggling families.

Wonga, which offers short-term loans of up to £1,000 at an annual interest rate of 5,853%, said loans to 1m customers in five countries had driven revenues across the group to £309.3m in 2012, up by 67% on the previous year. Net profits after tax were £62.5m, an increase of 36% on 2011's figure.

Wonga said that worked out as a net profit of about £15 on every loan, or 5p for every £1 lent.

It said the majority of its customers were "young, single, employed, digitally savvy and can pay us back on time" – but it admitted that "not all loans are profitable" and the annual results published on Tuesday revealed that the firm, which describes itself as a responsible lender, had also seen a sharp increase in the amount of bad debts on its books.

Wonga wrote off £96m and made a £126m provision for impairments in 2012, up from £44m and £67m respectively in 2011. Although it does not disclose how much of this was lost to bad debts or the fraud which has hit the firm, it admitted there had been a rise in the amount written off that related to customers "who are in unexpectedly difficult economic situations".

The lender, which has faced criticism from a wide range of sources, including the Archbishop of Canterbury who recently vowed to compete it out of business, said its profitability during 2012 was "the result of the large scale of our operations and an unflinching commitment to providing a flexible and convenient service designed around customers".

It added that it had "ambitions far beyond short-term consumer loans in the UK" and was now spending significant sums developing new products and markets, and would be investing in the business rather than paying a dividend.

Since its launch in 2007 Wonga has already expanded to employ 500 people and expects to grow that to 650 by the end of the year.

Although the company offers loans in five countries, including Canada, Poland and South Africa, and launched Wonga for Business in 2012, its UK retail lending operation remains at the heart of its business and profits.

Lending to UK consumers accounted for 3.8m of its 4m loans over the year, an increase of 58% on 2011's figure, and totalled £1.2bn, a 65% increase on the previous year. Corporation tax paid by the firm totalled £22m.

Wonga's founder and chief executive, Errol Damelin, said: "We are continuing to disrupt the financial services industry with our flexible, digital and data-driven approach.

"When we decided we wanted to provide short-term loans within 30 minutes, the incumbents told us it couldn't be done – but we found a way to do it responsibly, effectively and at scale. We will keep on challenging conventional practices, to provide customers with the service they want and deserve in the 21st century."

Industry under the spotlight

The payday loans industry is currently under scrutiny by the Competition Commission following a year-long review by the Office of Fair Trading. It found evidence of widespread bad practice and said firms were too often competing on speed of service to the detriment of consumers.

Wonga has already sent its submission to the Competition Commission and said its work "accords with our view that the short-term credit sector needs better, rather than more, regulation".

Stella Creasy, the Labour MP who has campaigned for a cap on the amount that payday lenders can charge consumers, said the news of Wonga's profits "should be of great concern to all of us in Britain".

"What that says about families who are struggling financially, what it says about the kind of regulation we currently have in the UK and the things we need to do to make sure people in Britain can borrow affordably – Wonga might be celebrating today, I am very, very concerned about what this might mean for people in my community and across the country who are paying the price for their profits."

Trade union Unite said the results reinforced the need for legislation to curb payday lenders. "Payday lenders are making their profits on those struggling to make ends meet on a daily basis with outrageous rates of interest that mount up with an alarming speed, causing fear and insecurity," the general secretary Len McCluskey said. "Ted Heath once spoke of the unacceptable face of capitalism – what we are seeing in 2013 is vulture capitalism, picking wallets and purses clean."

webTitle: FTSE 100 fades as Vodafone dips but Spirent and TalkTalk move higher

fields.standfirst: Testing company Spirent climbs as chief executive departs while TalkTalk benefits from upgrade
fields.body:
Technology companies are again in the spotlight, and not just Microsoft and Vodafone, with good gains so far for Spirent Communications and TalkTalk Telecom.

Spirent has jumped 6.3p to 134.9p after the telecoms testing company said chief executive Bill Burns was stepping down immediately, to be replaced by finance director Eric Hutchinson. The company gave no reason, and said Burns would help make a smooth transition. He would receive a payment in line with his contract. In due course, Spirent said it would start the search for a new chief executive. Analyst George O'Connor at Panmure Gordon said:

News that the chief executive departs is disappointing given that after a poor start there have been some positives from the company - note the second quarter book-to-bill. Also, comments from peers (namely Ixia and Anite) suggest that the operational weakness is primarily market driven.
Some will see the news as a portent of a poor order build for the third quarter; however, in our view it is more likely a degree of frustration at the pace of change and possibly failure to use the balance sheet more aggressively to hold the share price - compare and contrast with (say) the management teams at Micro Focus, Sage, Fidessa and Computacenter which have all used cash to prop up the share price. We note that Spirent's board composition has backgrounds at Sherborne Investors and The Carlyle Group - but also, very pleasingly, Sue Swenson. Sue is best known for 'fixing' Sage US, and has a very strong Telecoms pedigree - she can either pick the candidate or, even better, do the job herself. Mr Hutchinson, appointed January 2000, is a very safe pair of hands, who knows the company inside and outside and should do a good job in the meantime. Yes, investors will be cautious on the news, but we retain our buy and 169p target price.

Meanwhile TalkTalk has jumped 11.6p to 259.6p following a positive note from JP Morgan. The bank said TalkTalk's shares had been unfairly hit by news that BT would be offering its sports channel free to its broadband customers. It said:

Over the last year, TalkTalk has beaten expectations on TV adds and churn reduction, while pricing repair continues. The cost story is compelling with much still to do given its acquisitive history. Despite this, it has performed in-line with the FTSE 250 over 12 months, as overdone concerns on BT Sport weigh. We upgrade to overweight (from neutral) and increase our price target to 300p (from 225p).

Overall, leading shares have made a cautious start after Monday's surge on positive manufacturing surveys around the globe. The FTSE 100 has lost early gains and is currently 2.65p lower at 6503.54.

Land Securities is down 16.5p at 892p as JP Morgan edged down its price target from £11.10 to £10.40 but kept its overweight rating.

Vodafone has fallen 2.95p to 210.15p as profit takers moved in following Monday's confirmation after the market closed that it had agreed to sell its stake in Verizon Wireless for $130bn. Ronnie Chopra, head of strategy at Tradenext, said:

The massive dividend for shareholders of Vodafone seemed to be ignored by the market which seems rather surprising...the possible predators stalking telecom companies should make the UK telco giant on the radar of many. It seems to be very much buy on the rumour sell on the news. It will be interesting to see what Wall Street makes of the Vodafone [deal] when markets resume trading after their long weekend.

Elsewhere Genus, the animal genetics business, fell 101p to £13.78 after underlying full year profits dropped from £54.4m to £38.1m reflecting a fall in biological assets. Adjusted profits rose by 1% to £49.1m. Panmure Gordon moved from sell to hold, saying:

Genus has reported 2013 results slightly below our forecasts with adjusted earnings per share rising 3% to 55p (Panmure 56p). However anticipated good harvests in the Northern Hemisphere are likely to lower input costs and improve profitability in major end markets. As such Genus expects to deliver strong progress through 2014. We forecast a return more typical mid-teens earnings growth in 2014.

The bank said TalkTalk's shares had been unfairly hit by news that BT would be offering its sports channel free to its broadband customers. It said: Over the last year, TalkTalk has beaten expectations on TV adds and churn reduction, while pricing repair continues. The cost story is compelling with much still to do given its acquisitive history. Despite this, it has performed in-line with the FTSE 250 over 12 months, as overdone concerns on BT Sport weigh. We upgrade to overweight (from neutral) and increase our price target to 300p (from 225p). Overall, leading shares have made a cautious start after Monday's surge on positive manufacturing surveys around the globe. The FTSE 100 has lost early gains and is currently 2.65p lower at 6503.54. Land Securities is down 16.5p at 892p as JP Morgan edged down its price target from £11.10 to £10.40 but kept its overweight rating. Vodafone has fallen 2.95p to 210.15p as profit takers moved in following Monday's confirmation after the market closed that it had agreed to sell its stake in Verizon Wireless for $130bn. Ronnie Chopra, head of strategy at Tradenext, said: The massive dividend for shareholders of Vodafone seemed to be ignored by the market which seems rather surprising...the possible predators stalking telecom companies should make the UK telco giant on the radar of many. It seems to be very much buy on the rumour sell on the news. It will be interesting to see what Wall Street makes of the Vodafone [deal] when markets resume trading after their long weekend. Elsewhere Genus, the animal genetics business, fell 101p to £13.78 after underlying full year profits dropped from £54.4m to £38.1m reflecting a fall in biological assets. Adjusted profits rose by 1% to £49.1m. Panmure Gordon moved from sell to hold, saying: Genus has reported 2013 results slightly below our forecasts with adjusted earnings per share rising 3% to 55p (Panmure 56p). However anticipated good harvests in the Northern Hemisphere are likely to lower input costs and improve profitability in major end markets. As such Genus expects to deliver strong progress through 2014. We forecast a return more typical mid-teens earnings growth in 2014.

fields.standfirst: For Nokia, it means that a decades-long heritage as one of the world's leading mobile phone makers - which had been a source of huge pride in Finland - is over
fields.body: The deal, for €5.44bn (£4.6bn), gives Microsoft a company which used to dominate the mobile and smartphone market in 2006 but has been overshadowed by the rise of Apple and, latterly, Samsung and companies using Google's Android software.
